header.topics: Membership of a society, life information, some technical engineering subjects.
header.activity: Time off from working party in Creeh-St-Michael.

speaker.dialect_rep: I may have a slight Somerset accent
speaker.occupation: retired artist and antique dealer/gallery owner

body.u: I've been a model engin nothing to do with cataracts I've been a model engineer for nearly thirty years erm I've built three traction engines I'm now doing a railway engine built a number of stationary engines workshops been built up over the years several lathes different types different milling machines been a member of the club for model engineers for nearly thirty years and I'm here on a working party doing not a lot
so the background noises we can hear are other people working this morning erm can you tell me? er all the things you've done over the years what would you say erm was your biggest achievement?
probably the last traction engine mclaren compound
right and erm was that? can you tell me the erm where that originates from the Mclaren compound?
it was ordered by the War Office for service in the First World War but it never saw service but it wasn't completed until nineteen nineteen so it was surplus to requirements by that time
right

it went for road haulage but the road hauliers didn't like it they said it was too big converted to a showman's engine the showman didn't like it because they said it was too big and subsequently the wheels were cut back to make it better for british roads the steering was moved from one side to the other for the same reason and it went back into service as a road locomotive heavy haulage
oh right they are very dramatic I frequently see you at shows driving erm your steam engines erm what are you working on at the moment?
erm my first railway engine which is a
oh right
a narrow gauge engine at er seven and a quarter inch gauge but because it's a narrow gauge it works out at er almost third full size
oh right I see and how far down down the line are you working on that?
I've I've a I have a rolling chassis I've been on it a year next month
oh gosh so how much time do you put in every day?
about three hours a day
really?
yeah
that's real dedication
mm
one of the things that's always appealed to me about the model engineers is the people who do it are real engineers they're not train spotters they're not
oh no I'm not nnot really
they're they're not train set people
no I'm
not really into railways railways have always left me cold erm from the age of nine
oh right?
to twenty-one we lived in a cottage with a very long garden at the bottom of which was the mainline railway track
oh right?
and I wasn't a bit interested in the trains
oh right
back in the er the days of steam you'd be
yes
er specially in the summer if you had the door open
yes
and you hear a train coming and look out you could see the glow from the firebox as it went past
yes yeah yes
but erm my biggest erm thought of railways at that time was that they interinterrupted whatever I was listening to whether it was the television or what
you couldn't hear a thing as they trundled past
yeah well your trai your erm d engines here are a lot less noisy than that aren't they?
well of course they're a lot smaller yes
yeah and this has been a wonderful project on this field here er
it has it's had its ups and downs
yeah
it's not perfect but then whatever is?
yeah I remember when they first said because I used to live in erm er before I met twenty years ago
yeah
and erm when I lived here it was aaround the time that somebody bulldozed the pavilion do you remember that?
er no I don't actually remember it but I the story has been told to me on numerous occasions yeah
numerous occasions and I remember
they they stole a digger and demolished the pavilion yeah yeah
yes that's right that's absolutely right
yeah yeah

well I I remember reading it in the gazette and I said when you said you when they all said they were coming here from I thought my goodness oh dear I don't hold up much hope so I was quite pessimistic about it

erm because there has been a I mean there was one lady I don't know whether you know this in who gave a talk at hall she came from London to talk to a group and the group outside there was erm a group of boys and they banged on the windows and pounded on the doors and she was so terrified she said she would rather give a talk in London than she would in
really?
and that yeah that there was such you know the erm hall where

no when I was a teenager

these no these were youngsters

in Victorian England which I had found a collection of in a junk shop

and I talked about it and I've got still got them and they're wonderful and erm they said to me oh we hope it's not like last time and then they told me about it so that's how I knew
yeah right
of it really erm anyway erm so er the the erm project here has gone from strength to strength recently
